moves.8... Bc5: ...and my opponent does the same to mine...
moves.10... Bc5 11. Bc4 d6 12. Rf7: ...and put the rook on the attack.
moves.12... Bg4+ 13. Be2: I go for the blocking move...
moves.14... g5 15. d3: This opens up the remaining bishop...
moves.20. Bh6: This move allows me to launch an assault on the remaining rook...
moves.21... Rxf8 22. Bxf8: ...and get another exchange, with the bishop deep in enemy territory.
moves.22... h5 23. Be7 d5 24. Bxc5 Kxc5: I deemed it worth swapping bishops...
moves.25. exd5 Kxd5: ...and pawns, creating more space. Who would crack?
I decide to give my far left-hand pawn a start...
moves.35... Kb3 36. Kb5 c4 37. a4: I think my opponent resigned here because the response to Kxb2 would be Kxc4, and my a-pawn would have a clear run, whilst the response to c3 would be bxc3, and again my a-pawn can't be caught.

gameName: No queens or knights... how will you do? II
